Name: Kansas City Scene
Description:
Kansas City Scene is a Monopoly variant taking place in set in the KS/MO city. The board spaces are late 1970s-era business from the city.

Part of the Hansen's City Scene Games Series.

From the publisher: Have you ever wanted to own the Kansas City Chiefs, Macy's, the Kansas City Star, or run the Board of Trade? Now is your chance by playing Kansas City Scene.

Name: San Antonio & Austin Scene
Description:
San Antonio & Austin Scene is a Monopoly variant taking place in set in the Texas cities. The board spaces are late 1970s-era business from those cities.

Part of the Hansen's City Scene Games Series.

From the publisher: Wheel and deal in the oil industry, command an air force base, persuade an ethnic leader, and attempt to influence a politician or two - all in San Antonio & Austin Scene.

Name: Cincinnati Scene
Description:
Cincinnati Scene is a Monopoly variant taking place in set in Cincinnati, OH. The board spaces are late 1970s-era business from the city.

Part of the Hansen's City Scene Games Series.

From the publisher: Have you ever wanted to own the Cincinnati Reds, Procter & Gamble, Indian Hill, or run the Cincinnati Enquirer? Now is your chance by playing Cincinnati Scene.

Name: New Orleans Scene
Description:
New Orleans Scene is a Monopoly variant taking place in set in New Orleans, LA. The board spaces are late 1970s-era business from the city.

Part of the Hansen's City Scene Games Series.

From the publisher: Wheel and deal on the Waterfront, befriend a glamorous socialite, explore the French Quarter, and retain a shrewed lawyer to stay out of trouble - all part of the New Orleans Scene.

Name: Denver Scene
Description:
Denver Scene is a Monopoly variant taking place in set in Denver, CO. The board spaces are late 1970s-era business from Denver.

Part of the Hansen's City Scene Games line.

From the publisher: Influence the Water Board, make the Canadian connection, join the right club, and deal with the old-moneyed businesses - all part of the Denver Scene.

Name: Utah on Board
Description: Utah on Board is a Monopoly clone based on the state of Utah. Board squares are replaced with landmarks, tourist attractions, and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Utah based charities.

Name: Hi-Ho! Santa Claus Game
Description:
You use a spinner to go around the board, trimming the tree in this old Christmas holiday-themed game.

OBJECT: To be the first player to put his 8 colored balls and Santa Claus on the Christmas Tree.

Players spin the spinner once each turn. If the spinner lands on his color, he may put one of his colored balls in the hole on the Christmas tree that shows the matching color. If the spinner lands on the tree, he must remove one of his colored balls from the tree. If a player spins Santa Claus before he has 8 balls on the tree, he can spin again. Once a player has all his 8 balls on the tree, he spins on his turn for Santa Claus. When he has all 8 balls and spins Santa Claus, he yells out "Hi Ho! Santa Claus!", thus winning the game!

Name: The Pillars of the Earth: New Craftsmen
Description:
This expansion to the base game is available in the Spielbox magazine 6/07.
They are also included in The Pillars of the Earth Expansion Set! (Mayfair Games edition only!) and in the German special edition

The new craftsmen cards in this expansion are:

     Beggar (Bettler)
     Day Laborer (Tagelöhner)
     Tinsmith (Zinngießer)
     Goldsmith (Goldschmied)
     Market Warden (Marktwart)
     Gardener (Gartenbauer)


From the publisher:

"Here are six new craftsmen you can add to your Pillars of the Earth games! They are compatible with both the basic game and the expansion. These craftsmen are mixed together with the ones in the basic game (and the expansion if you are using it). But the number of craftsmen available is not increased. In 2-4 player games, only four craftsmen are available each round, as normal (two on the spaces in Shiring, and two below the board with the resource cards). In 5 or 6 player games, there are five craftsmen each round (three below the board). Before the game begins, randomly remove one craftsman from each round, and return them unseen to the box."

Buy Microbadges

Pillars of the Earth Fan
Families: Series: The Pillars of the Earth (Kosmos)

Name: Pug-I-Lo
Description: The Pug-I-Lo Boxing Board Game was published by the Pug-I-Lo Game Company of Zullinger PA in 1960. The box claims that the game is about the Complete game of Boxing. You are  the Commisioner, Manager and Fighter in this game The game comes with Play Money and Playing Cards and was designed by Marvin Ogle

Name: Kokoa kuva
Description:
Game for children Ages 4 and up.

Kokoa kuva (Build a picture) is a nice game full of funny animal pictures. One animal picture is formed of two cards. In the game you search the cards and then you can build the picture.

It's a colorful memory game that even the youngest in the family can win. Precise observations and good memory are keys to victory.

By combining cards you can create 552 funny animals like "mousebat" or "fishduck".

Name: De Kolonisten van Catan: Wegwerpcatan
Description:
Wegwerpcatan ("disposable Catan") is a free promotional version of Settlers of Catan, given away by Dutch publisher 999 Games.

The game is completely made of paper and can be used a few times. Rules are simplified: no cards are used in this version, no robber. The player who gets to 7 points wins.

Instead of dice, Wegwerpcatan uses a spinner which you have to assemble yourself. Every player has a set of tiles to rotate and represent the number of resources you own or gain. The board layout is fixed, as are the positions of the starting settlements and roads.

Name: Deckarspelet
Description: Deckarspelet (English, the Detective's game) is a card game for children based on the popular books and television shows about Lassemajas detektivbyrå (English, Lassemajas detective agency).

Name: Japanese Task Force 2: Carrier Battles in the Pacific, 1944
Description:
Blind system carrier warfare in Pacific Ocean using inverted counters and dummies.

The designer of this game is " Easy & Exciting Game (EEG) wargame design coterie".

Name: Bruce Lee
Description:
Old Polish game inspired by simple computer version of Bruce Lee game. Even on the boardgame box is written "Bruce Lee - Computer Game without computer".

In fact this is classic roll and move game. Bruce Lee explores Abby levels, fights encountered enemies, and tries to complete four mission objectives. Bruce Lee can use some equipment, and use special moves-spells.

When there is more than one player in game, everyone leads his own Bruce Lee, or some players are ninja leaders, and try to disturb Lee in his quest.

Name: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing: Shopping
Description:
Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing-Shopping Set "is designed to help your child learn about earning, saving, and shopping wisely." The set contains 3 Main Games and 2 Introductory Games

The Introductory games introduce the board and cards to younger children.

Game 1 Fun to Earn: Uses the bottom half of the Board. Players take Job Cards from the Home space to their respective Earning Places and trade them for a Sesame Street Coupon. The first player to save 3 Coupons wins.

Game 2 Shop and Swap: Uses the top half of the Board. Players get Shopping List Cards from the Home space, move to the correct Store, and pay the listed Coupon for the correct Item. The first player to complete 3 Shopping trips wins.

Game 3 Big Bird's Surprise Birthday Party: This Combines the ideas of game 1 and 2. Players earn Coupons by completing Jobs, and then buy the items from their Shopping Lists. The first player to bring 2 items Home for Big Bird's Party wins.

Name: Candy Land: Fun on the Run
Description:
From the publisher: "Every child’s first game in a new compact size for fun on the run! Move along the candy path and be first to reach the Candy Castle and win the game! No reading required to play."

The change for this travel game from the traditional game is the inclusion of a spinner to determine movement instead of the usual cards.

Re-implements:

    Candy Land

Name: Abracadabra
Description:
Children's game consisting of a central game board with 9 different illustrations, and 36 tiles that each have one of those illustrations on them. The players take turns picking a tile and placing it in front of them, where it has to touch a previous tile horizontally or vertically, as shown on the central board. The first to get all 9 wins.

A variant has the players place the tiles directly on the central game board and try to form three-in-a-row.

Name: Futebol S.A.
Description:
In this game players act as technical/owner of football clubs. 
Buying the best players and putting them on the field in the best way to defeat their opponents. So recruiting new fans for his club.

Name: Loose Files and American Scramble
Description:
Wargaming Battles of the American War of Independence.
Fast rules for quick and dirty play.

Originally published in Wargames Illustrated No. 1, Sept 1987.

Name: Scrabble Poker
Description: Use Scrabble tiles printed on cards to make words and place bets with either seven card stud or Hold 'Em style. Package includes a deck of 66 cards. Deluxe set includes 100 cards and a set of four-color poker chips.

Name: 1789: Le Jeu de la Révolution Francaise
Description:
Game of the French Revolution

On a map of Paris in 1789, up to 6 Players have to obtain "certificats de civisme" by moving their character in the city (rolling a die) and taking part in historical events (gaining points - assignats - by answering questions on special locations). Once they have collected enough assignats they can retrieve the certificates in key Parisian Revolutionary locations:
l'Hotel de Ville - city Hall
la Bastille
les Tuileries
le Pantheon
le Champ de Mars.
Other events (spaces on the map / special cards) can alter the moves of the players or even let them win or lose the precious certificates.
The winner is the first player to obtain 5 certificates

By some of the same designers as La Révolution Francaise (Azure Wish)

Name: TCHAD Manta 83
Description:
What if game

The Libyan Army, GUNT forces and Islamic legion against the French Army, Chadian forces and united Zairoise forces in TChad in 1983.

1 hex : 35 km
1 turn : 24 h
15 turns
1 mapboard : A3

Rules : 8 pages with different tables

Counters are to be cut out and to be stuck

This game was published in the French magazine "Le journal du Stratège" for July, August, September 1990

Name: Urgent fury
Description:
Wargame on the U.S. led invasion of Grenada in 1983.
Solo game
The player controls US forces

Turn : 8
Rules 3 pages
1 mapboard : A4
Counters are to be cut and to be gone up (76 counters)

This game was published in the magazine "Le journal du stratège" n° 58/59 in 1991.

Name: Hobble-de-hoy!
Description:
A Hobble-de-hoy is which one of these:

1. 17th century cabinetmaker's tool used for drilling peg holes in hard woods.

2. A young shepherd.

3. An affectionate greeting between crippled sailors.

4. Nonsense, confusion.  Also a stew of vegetables, meat, and broth; hotchpotch.

5. An awkward, callow youth.

6. A wooden toy of colonial times; currently still made in remote mountain communities.

7. A mariner's cry when a whale becomes entangled in a harpoon line.

8. Trade name for a breakfast cereal made from a species of seaweed.

Well, which one?

Hobble-de-hoy! is a published version of an old parlor game, Dictionary.  It consists of a single hardbound book, a little over 9" high (23 cm).  The book contains complete instructions, a word list of 1001 words, and, in the back of the book, definitions from the Oxford English Dictionary for the 1001 words (reprinted with permission).

The book can be opened from either end - flip it over, and it appears to be right-side up from either side.  One side brings you to the word list, the other to the definition list.  Each word and definition are numbered so you can match them up easily.

As in the traditional game, players take turn finding an obscure word and announcing it to the group.  Everyone writes down a definition for the word, while the player in charge writes down the official definition.  The player in charge of the word then shuffles the definitions, reads them through once, then reads them again.  Players voting for the correct definition get 2 points, while players whose word was selected as correct by someone else get 1 point for each selection.

The word list is a very interesting selection of some of the more obscure words in the Oxford English Dictionary.  In the parlor game, a player has to thumb through a dictionary looking for an obscure word.  In this book, you won't recognize at least 98% of the words!  The title of the game is one such word, meaning an awkward, callow youth.  (Did you get that right?)  Some of the lovelier sounding words chosen include quemeful, poculary, bewscher, dedolence, cawquaw, wicopy, timwhisky, etc.  And did you know there's a word that has the definition, "Excessive use of the letter R"?

Name: Eendenjacht
Description:
From the back of the box


     The aim of the game is to shoot down the ducks of your colour.
     Put balls into your handset according to the colour of your choice.
     Press the house in the center of the turntable to start the game
     Shoot to knock down the ducks of your colour as they swirl around. Beware! Do not knock down the other coloured ducks as your opponents will have the advantages!
     The first person to shoot down all the ducks of his colour is the winner

Name: Master Europa 101: Eastern Front
Description:
Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series.

This module covers the games "Fire in the East", "Scorched Earth", and "Urals". It contains 8 new counters for use with the new logistics system.

Name: Space Marine Battles
Description:
This book Space Marine Battles is a supplement for 2nd edition Space Marine. It is a compilation of articles from White Dwarf Magazine split into four sections:

    Tactics
    Battle Reports
    New Rules
    Modeling Workshop


The new rules introduced in this book included Daemon Engines of Tzeentch, Epic Personalities (Unique Characters for the game), Additional Titans & Garguants (these rules were superceded when Titan Legions was released) and Assult (rules for attacking fortifications)

Expands

    Space Marine

Name: Fast Mail
Description: The game consists of a game board, spinner and six tokens. There are three tokens for each player, representing a Fast Mail train, an Accommodation train , and a Freight train.  Certain "rules of the road" apply (e.g. A Freight train must wait on a siding until a Fast Mail passes). The object is to be the first player to move all of your trains from one station to another.
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Folko-Boks
Description:
Folko-Boks is a boxing-themed abstract pure strategy game.  The game lasts 10 rounds in a ring of 36 squares, randomly initialized with numbered chits. In each round, players move their boxers like a chess knight, removing the numbered marker from the square they left.  The boxer who moves onto a higher numbered square wins that round.  Being unable to move causes a knockout loss.

Folko-Boks was included as a free game in issue 4 of the Polish board gaming magazine Åšwiat Gier Planszowych ("World of Boardgames") published December 2007.

The game acknowledges some inspiration from an earlier game by Sid Sackson, probably Paper Boxing.
There is a somewhat similar game Joust on an 8x8 grid.

Name: Master Europa 102: Western Front – Invasion
Description:
Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series.

This module covers the game Second Front. It contains 143 new counters for use with the logistics system.

Name: Master Europa 103: Western Front – Blitzkrieg
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the games "Fall of France" & "Their Finest Hour". It contains 19 new counters for use with the logistics system, 3 for the German OOB, and 49 for use with the naval system . It also includes Orders Of Battle (OOB) that allow a scenario showing the Western Front from Sept. 1939 on to be explored.

Name: Master Europa 104: Southern Front
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the game "War in the Desert" (or the older "Torch", "Western Desert", and "Near East" games). It contains 122 new counters for use with the logistics system.

Name: Master Europa 105: SouthEastern Front
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the game "Balkan Front". It contains 47 new counters for use with the logistics system and 1 each for the German and Italian OOB.

Name: Master Europa 106: First Front
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the game "First to Fight". It contains no counters.

Name: Master Europa 107: Northern Fronts
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the games "Narvik" & "Storm over Scandinavia" & "Winter War". It contains 39 new counters for use with the logistics system, and 1 for use with the naval system .

Name: Master Europa 108: Red Army
Description:
Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series.

This module provides the player with all the materials needed to make use of the latest research available on the entire Soviet military during the years 1939-1945. 
Over 6,000 counters provide a complete replacement Soviet military and production structure. These counters will work with the existing GRD products, but avoid the "gaps" where the new games have not filled in.
A special set of rules allows this module to be integrated into either Master Europa modules 101 or 102 without difficulty.

Name: Master Europa 109: Partisan!
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module provides the player with a complete set of rules, Orders of Appearances, and counters to allow the player to simulate the underground war in the West and Balkans from 1940-1945. It contains 570 counters for use with the system.

Name: Master Europa 110: Strategic Air War
Description:
Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series.

This module provides the entire German production system, Orders of Battle and counters presenting the RAF (and its Commonwealth country counterparts), the Luftwaffe from 1939-1945, and the United States Army Air Force in the Mediterranean and Northern European Theaters from 1942-1945. It contains 1,909 counters (625 Luftwaffe, 650 RAF, 514 USAAF, and 124 target and special markers for the Germans).

Name: Master Europa 111: War at Sea
Description:
Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series.

This module provides a comprehensive naval system for all of Master Europa, and includes a map showing the full Atlantic and Indian oceans. The module contains ship cards showing the fleets of every European nation, the US Atlantic fleet, Brazil, India, and the Japanese fast carrier fleet. The module covers from Sept. 1939 to June 1945. It contains 1046 ship cards and 887 new counters: 195 showing the carrier and land based aircraft, 189 coastal defense positions, 146 Task force Markers, and 357 for use in the interlocking convoy system.

Name: Master Europa 112: Grand Master Europa
Description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module provides a consolidated and unified set of rules (General and National) and charts to allow all games in the series to be united and played as a single mass. You must have the other modules (except 108) for this to be used.

Name: Idiot's Pursuit
Description:
Subtitle: The satirical trivia set

A set of 56 expansion cards for trivia games, intended to be used to spike the decks of other trivia games. 
Categories: 
God & Creation
Hitler & The Gang
Sex & Minorities
Aliens & Other Animals
Sports & Lesions
Excrement & Showbiz

Sample Questions:
Q: What do American Indian paratroopers shout?
A: Custer!

Q: What builds strong bodies 12 ways? 
A: 12 kinds of regular exercise.

Q: What does a second throw into the ring to stop a boxing match?
A: A .38 [pistol]

Name: Frog
Description:
One of Haba's Mini-Spiels that come in a small tin and contain small wooden pieces.

A flicking game for 2 to 4 jolly jumping players. Contains 4 sets of wooden frogs and matching coloured flicking disks. All players go simultaneously in an attempt to be the first to flick their frog back into the pond (the empty tin)

Name: Victory in the Galaxy
Description:
Small game, published on Tactics magazine in Japan.
Though it is really a small magazine game, this game covers all aspects of galactic warfare.
The key point is that at the start every power has really very limited capacity.  Because of this reason, the small map is really big enough for expanding, and even the regular capacity for other game is really a special ability.
Very clever design.
But unfortunately even in Japan this game is neglected, because this game is attached with not the boardgame issue but with the RPG issue.
If you found this in the auction and you love sci-fi boardgames, please take it.

Name: Age of Battles: 1242 – Battle of Lake Peipus
Description:
Minis-based game using a generous selection of 1/72 miniatures, provided, depicting the fierce battle that transpired between Russian and Livonian knights on the ice of Lake Peipus in 1242, in Estonia.  Comes with 72 very high quality plastic  soldiers, rules of play, several play aids and a few cardboard tents that need to be cut out and assembled.  Packaging is in Russian and English but the game is available with rules in German, French, Spanish, Italian and Dutch.

This game is one of four in the Age of Battles medieval series.

Name: Gotcha
Description:
Gotcha is a board game created in the 1980's by a division of a jewelery company (Roset by Reid) based in Medicine Hat, Alberta, Canada.

The goal of the game is to create rows of 5 chips in your color across a board divided up into rows of colored and numbered squares.  On his turn, the player will play one of 5 cards from his hand of cards, each of which have a number and a color on them.  The information on this card indicates a limited set of squares on the board matching the color and number on which a chip can be placed.  There are also 2 special kinds of cards: Wild cards which allow a chip to be placed anywhere, and Gotcha cards which can be used to remove an opponent's chip from the board.

A round is over once a player has created 2 rows of 5 chips.  Each row of 5 garners 50 points.  Several rounds are played until one player reaches 500 points and is declared the winner.

This game can also be played in 2 or 3 teams of 2 players each.

Name: The Eternity Game
Description:
The Eternity Game is a Biblical trivia game for players ages 12 and up.  Players answer questions in one of 5 different categories: Characters, Words, History, Geography, and Miscellaneous, and these questions are in 3 levels of difficulty: Easy, Harder, or Hardest.

The goal is to be the first person to move their token across the board to reach the space indicating "Eternity with Jesus".  A player simply answers a question taken from one of the hundreds of question cards corresponding to the color of the space their token is on.  The color of the space indicates the question's category and the number on the space indicates the difficulty level of the question.  If answered correctly, the player rolls the die and moves accordingly.  Should a player be unable to answer a question, the player on their next turn may attempt a lower level of question in the same category.

This game can be played in teams.  There are also "Advanced Play" rules, in which the die is not used.  In this rule set, once a player answers a question correctly, the token is moved ahead on the board the same number of spaces as the level answered (1, 2, or 3), and the player retains her turn until an incorrect answer is given.

Name: Call to Arms
Description:
Call to Arms is the second supplement for Lightning Strike, completing the space-based rules set with provisions for advanced ECM, minefields, unit variants and space stations. In addition to twenty-four new CEGA and Jovian units, vehicles used by the neutral Mercurian Merchant Guild are also presented. Within these covers you will find:


     Full rules and data cards for fielding the exo-armors, fighters and warships of Jupiter, Earth and Mercury;



     Advanced rules for new weapons, cargo and low orbit battles;



     Two full-color counter sheets


DP9-318, 32 pages +counters

SRP $15.95US/$17.50Can

NOTE: Call to Arms is not a stand-alone game. You will need to own Lightning Strike in order to play it.

Expands:

    Lightning Strike

Name: Voltaire
Description:
Voltaire is a word game for one (or two) players. The purpose of the game is to cross words, aiming at placing all the letters on the grid.

The player draws at random 10 of the 48 letter tiles, then forms a two- to nine-letter word on the grid. The player then draws the same number of pieces as the letters played, so as to still have 10 letters at their disposal. A new word is formed, adding horizontally or vertically, to the previous word. And so on. The player continues placing words, with the goal being to dispose of all 48 letters. (Parallel words are allowed providing all letters form a word. Also, two words should always be separated by a free square.)

Difficulty Levels
To make the game easier, take out a number of pieces, taking care to remove as many vowels as consonants. To make a harder game: before starting, draw one or several letters and place them anywhere on the grid, blank side up. These will be dead squares, as in a crossword puzzle. OR you can reveal the letters, then "cross words according to the normal rule, incorporating the pieces already disposed on the grid."

Game contents:
Wooden game board with 9x9 grid and grooves along each edge to hold letter tiles, 48 wooden letter tiles (letters of the alphabet plus one joker).

Name: Jim Prentice Electric Football
Description: 1950s era Electric Football game. Players select offensive play and defensive formation and press buttons. Light bulbs light up a chart on the board to indicate the result of the play and yardage gained. A metal marker is moved along the edge of the "field" to indicate line of scrimmage and line to gain.

Name: The Denbury Resources Oil Game
Description:
[From the "Rules of the Game" booklet]:

OBJECTIVE
The object of the Oil Game is to add the most oil reserves by taking carbon dioxide from Jackson Dome to the old oil fields in the region.

Each player "transports" carbon dioxide along the pipeline by moving his/her token along the pipeline and claims the tertiary oil reserves from each oil field that is reached.

The winner is the player who either accumulates the most oil or reaches the winning target for the number of competitors playing.

Remember that this game differs from the real world because Denbury had the only carbon dioxide source in the area.  Effectively, it's like playing this game with only one player!

-
-

[comment by tcanderson71, an oil geologist in Wyoming]: Actually, this is very much like the real world -- here in Wyoming, there is only one current CO2 supply, owned and controlled by ExxonMobil, located in the LaBarge Field in southwestern Wyoming. It feeds into a CO2 pipeline delivering it to Chevron in Rangely Field in northwest Colorado, then Anadarko Petroleum at Monell Field and Merit Energy in the Lost Soldier and Wertz Fields (south-central Wyoming), and finally to Anadarko at the Salt Creek Field in east-central Wyoming.

Name: Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Model 505
Description: 1950's era electronic baseball game. Players press buttons that determine the pitch (good, bad) and the batter action (swing, take). Balls and strikes are called by light bulbs lighting up. Hits are determined by an electric motor spinner. Pegs are moved on the board to indicate base runners, balls, strikes, and outs.

Name: Prosperity
Description: A cross between Life and Monopoly with a Monopoly styled board.  This was self-published and has a very groovy 70s cover style and amateur feel to it.  You basically are trying to get enough money to be debt free and own a home (no remaining mortgage left).  First one able to do it wins.  there are some options on who you can control how many dice you roll (normally it is two, but you can pay money to allow you to roll only one or three).  Other than that, it is pretty luck-oriented with Paydays, Inheritance, and Jackpots you can hit.

Name: Last Night on Earth Special Edition Soundtrack CD
Description:
New Special Edition Game Soundtrack for Last Night on Earth features 16 tracks of music created specifically for the game. This includes the entire original soundtrack plus five new songs inspired by upcoming expansions. The CD features new artwork and liner notes from the composer and two exclusive new game cards only available with the Special Edition Soundtrack.

Guitar - Force a zombie to re-roll any number of its fight dice.

Dance of the Dead - Roll a d6 and remove that many Zombies, all remaining zombies may move one space.
Families: Series: Last Night on Earth Game Engine (Flying Frog Production)

Name: Pocky Shock
Description: The game is shaped like a box of Pocky, a favorite snack in Japan.  Two of the Pockys in the box are spring-loaded and pulling them will cause all of the Pockys to fly out.  Players take turns pulling Pockys; if you pull one of the spring-loaded ones, you lose.

Name: Swimming with Sharks
Description:
Swimming with Sharks is a strategy game where players are controlling either Swimmer pieces or Shark pieces.  Each player has 5 movement points to spend each turn, divided up among their pieces.  The Swimmer side also has a Boat piece.  Each piece has a movement cost.

When pieces move, they must go in two directions (like a Knight in Chess).  If a piece can move 4 spaces, it can move 1 in one direction and 3 in another, or 2 and 2.

The object for the Swimmers is to have at least one Swimmer make it to shore on the opposite side of the board.  The Sharks must prevent all Swimmers from making it.

The Boat is a protector, and as long as a Swimmer is in an adjacent space, a Shark can not take the piece.

There are 3 spaces marked with a Star.  When a player moves their piece onto the Star space, they may draw a card.

Cards typically consist of value amounts you can add to your movement for a turn.  There are a number of special cards that can affect either or both teams.  Players may hold as many cards as they like.  Movement cards have no penalty to play, but special cards require the use of some movement points in order to be played.

Name: Trollskatten
Description: Trollskatten (English, The Troll Treasure) is a Swedish children's game. The object of the game is to find the key to the treasure chest containing the troll's gold, while avoiding the evil troll and his traps. The first player to reach the gold wins.

Name: Pirate Hunters
Description:
A cutlass slashes through the sea breeze, smoke fills the air, a shout of "prepare for boarders!" echoes across the water, two ships pull closer as men run to the rails. You are about to enter the world of Pirate Hunters. Pirate adventure through the sea fights and battles for fame.

Fight your way across the seas in this game of sword fights and sea battles…

Pirate Hunter showcases man to man sword fights in the style of Worthington's popular COWBOYS game. Cards will reflect the variables of the fighting style of the golden age of piracy as well as some of the personality unique to this time. Players assume the roles of captains and their crews, opposing the English, Spanish, and American soldiers and sailors pitted against them.

The game includes plastic pirates crew, captains, multiple hard mounted game boards, cards, and much more, all produced with some of the highest quality game components available.

The game is playable by 2 to 3 players.  The game plays in 1 hour.

Name: What's Up Doc? The Bugs Bunny Game
Description:
Honey Bunny (TM) wants you to bring your friends along to Bugs Bugs Bunny's house, you will stop and pick up a birthday present from many of his Looney Tunes (TM) friends.

Object:  To collect a present from all of Bugs Bunny's friends and bring them to his birthday party.

Name: Strive For Five: Old Testament
Description:
From the box:

Strive For Five is a competitive educational game that is fun for the whole family.

Each card starts with a true or false question. The correct answer will win you the right to play the card. Each youth and pre-school card has 5 multiple choice questions (per side). Each Adult card has 5 questions (per side) with an alphabetical clue to the answer. Can be played with or without the clue.

You must "Strive For Five" correct answers because the person who answers the 5th question, wins the card. If the turn is passed to you on the 5th question, you could win the card with only one correct answer, keeping the excitement level high.

Youth, pre-school, adult and expert cards can be played in the same game for family play.

Name: Time on Target: April 1945 – At The Sharp End
Description:
Advanced Squad Leader System (ASL) compatible - Battles between the German 2nd Marine Infantry Division and the British VIII and XII Corps. 6-19 April 1945.

Contents:
20 Scenarios
5 Overlays
32 Special Counters needed for the play of the scenarios
Historical Background

ASL rulebook, British and German counters, and ASL mapboards needed.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader


Scenarios:
TOT 13: Learning the Law of the Soldier
TOT 14: Panzer-Teufel Strikes Back
TOT 15: The Steel-Eyed Boys
TOT 16: The Strassengabel Strongpoint
TOT 17: Last Stand at Westen
TOT 18: The Aller Waltz
TOT 19: Liebe Elefriede
TOT 20: Threat to the Bridgehead
TOT 21: Tony - Take the Bridge - Out!
TOT 22: Rock of Resistance
TOT 23: This Close to the Sharp End
TOT 24: Across the Aller
TOT 25: Franzen's Roadblock
TOT 26: Free-for-All
TOT 27: First Light of Dawn
TOT 28: Black Friday
TOT 29: Tiger Hunt
TOT 30: Right Hook at Sudkampen
TOT 31: Push Comes to Shove
TOT 32: Denoument
TOT tB: Marine Ambush

Name: Chicago Cribbage
Description:
About the Game (from the Outset Media Website and the Package)

• Ages 10 and up
• 2-4 Players

An exciting twist to the traditional game of cribbage, where players can demand a recut, stall their opponents, trade hands, and even prevent 'fifteens' from scoring. At the beginning of each game players are dealt seven special cards to be used during that game, adding a new level of strategy and fun. Have you been dealt lousy cards? No worries! Play the right card at the right time and watch your luck change instantly.

Contents

• Illustrated 54 card deck
• 28 special cards
• Instruction booklet

Name: Yahtzee: Dragon Ball Z
Description:
Like the classic Yahtzee game, you're rolling for various dice combinations.  Match Heroes - SS Goku, SS Trunks, and SS Vegeta or Villains - Android 20, Android 17 or Frieza 5th form to earn tiles.  The tiles add a different twist to the game, influencing your strategy plan.  They may provide you with Dragonball Z Radar or give you an extra roll or two of the dice.  You could even lose tiles to Perfect Cell.  Pick a Villain tile and you'll have to battle to keep it.

The more tiles you earn, the more points you'll score.  Roll Five of a Kind - that's Yahtzee, and you get to collect the Dragonball Tile along with any tiles collected by Perfect Cell.  Earn the most points and you win.

This unique combination of battle, chance and strategy makes every game exciting.

Name: Vencer o Morir: Kundt's Pocket at Camp Via, Dec. 1933
Description:
Vencer o Morir (to win or die) covers the largest single battle of the Chaco War in December, 1933.
Known as the Battle of Campo Via, the Paraguayan’s had massed (with the knowledge of the Bolivians’ air reconnaissance) twice as many   divisions aimed at the thinly defended lines and no Bolivian reserves. Just north of Alihuata, the Bolivian lines simply dangled. The warnings Kundt received from his own commanders along the front were all ignored. Fearing the worse, the Bolivian commander, Banzer, ordered part of his
artillery, his tanks and ammo to be moved south to Saavedra.
The battle began Dec. 3 and ended on the 12th.

Game Scale:
The map scale is about 2 miles per hex.
Each combat unit is a battalion sized unit. HQ’s are represented by a Paraguayan or Bolivian flag.
A game turn represents one day.
Tanks and Armor cars represent one of each type.
Artillery are batteries.

Name: Burial Ground
Description:
Tales tell of gold in the hills, and also stories of Zombies. For some strange reason the prospectors are turning into flesh hungry ghouls. For you, digging for gold is still high on the agenda, but with the walking dead infesting the area it isn't going to be such an easy task.

The objective is for the players to move around the board, digging for gold, or digging holes for the zombies to fall into (where they are more easily dispatched). Both methods reward the players with points. But there is always the threat of each action drawing the unwelcome attention of the roaming Zombies.

The zombies movement phases are in-game driven, and Cut-throat gameplay often sees other players placed between the target and the marauding ghouls.

Name: Las 7 Puertas
Description:
In this Dungeon Crawler game, you must explore the seven rooms of the temple in order to achieve the seven spheres of power of your scepter to defeat Karnú the immortal dragon.

In every room you must avoid the traps, resolve the hieroglyphics, defeat your enemies. Then you'll find magic treasures and weapons that allow you defeat your most powerful enemies.

Name: Quizimaze
Description: Quizimaze combines knowledge, strategy and luck into one game.  The object is to manipulate the existing maze into a dynamic everchanging maze to facilitate your moves in order to score and at the same time delay your opponents from scoring by trapping them in the maze.  All the while obtaining points from four categories, science & technology, arts & language, social studies and leisure & games.  To win quizimaze you must answer questions correctly and manipulate the maze to your advantage.

Name: Nancy Drew Mystery Party Game: One Step Ahead
Description:
From the publisher's website (http://www.aneveningofmurder.com/nancy_drew.htm):

The Nancy Drew Mystery Party Game has all the ingredients of an unforgettable event, including invitations, an easy-to-follow parents' guide and posters to identify game-play locations for quick and easy set-up. A CD narrated by Nancy instructs players how to work together to find and interpret clues around the house, on the net at www.playnancydrew.com or by calling a toll-free number.

You and your guests take on the roles of amateur detectives and work as a team to help Nancy solve her latest mystery. To do this you will set the stage for a visit to River Heights where you will collect clues from various locations including the scene of the crime, Lucia's Psychic Shop, the CyberCafé and Bookstore, and the River Heights Police Stations - all in the comfort of your own home.

Game set up and party planning are made easy with the inclusion of invitations, loot bags, and a detailed host's guide - everything you need to set the stage.

Each Mystery Party Game comes equipped with:

* 8 Invitations and envelopes
    * 8 Loot bags
    * Narrated CD
    * 5 posters of locations in River Heights
    * Map of River Heights and surrounding area
    * 8 Sleuth's notepads
    * Envelope containing clues
    * Mug shots of 3 suspects
    * Web and phone clues

Name: Drop-Xianqi
Description:
In this game, one uses Shogi pieces to represent Xiangqi [or in a variant Changgi] pieces or a Xiangqi board. One then incorporates the drop-mechanism of Shogi into the game, with all the restrictions of that game. This makes the games quite different.

Drop Xiangqi is a pure abstract game, basically a variant of Xiangqi played with the same equipment as the standard game and easily different enough to be considered a different game. Basically the pieces in Xiangqi just have the name of the piece written on it in Chinese. So there's a definitely up and down to the piece's orientation.

Ownership of pieces is then marked by whoever has the writing "right-side up" from his point of view. In lieu of moving a piece on the board, a captured piece may be placed on the board instead with the restriction that the piece must have a legal move from its position when placed and that no two pawns owned by the same player can be on the same file.

How this differs from the parent game:
Both are of the chess family of games an they share the game goal. Like the original, it's a pure abstract where the object is to capture the opponent's jade general. The key difference is that the complexity of the board situation does not get reduced during play. All pieces are always in play throughout the game, and so one will never have an end-game with only a few pieces involved. Exchanges don't remove pieces but rather potentially hand of vital material to one's opponent to use against you. Thus, what will be a good move in xiangqi can often be disastrous in drop-xiangqi and vice-versa. (The inspiration here is drawn from shogi.)

Capture the leader abstracts typically reduce to a simple end-game with the exception of shogi family of games. This game offers a complex end-game in a situation so that aplayer can't simply force exchanges to make a simple tactical game.

Name: The Little Engine That Could
Description:
This game recreates the story of "The Little Engine That Could."  Each player is a toy trying to get over the mountain and into the city.  There are four toy choices: a teddy bear, a plush elephant, a doll, and a monkey wearing a fez.

The first player is the player with the closest upcoming birthday and spins the arrow.  The spinner has blue squares, yellow stars, pink hearts, purple triangles, and green clowns.  If the player spun to the green clown, the player takes a second turn.  A player that ends his or her turn at the bridge can take a shortcut.  The first person to get to the city wins.

Name: Legends of Time and Space: Oasis
Description:
From the back of the booklet:

You sign on with the Andromeda Mining Corporation's reverted worlds reclamation project--a high paying gig with few risks. When tasked to recover an errant probe, you look forward to another boondoggle until you land on Oasis, and find that it isn't what you bargained for.

Oasis is a Ready/Play role-playing adventure for solitaire or group play. It is suitable for one to four players, age 12 and up.  This complete game includes the adventure book, rules, pieces, and game board.  It is compatible with The Fantasy Trip (R) and GURPS.

This is the second game in the Legends of Time and Space.
Families: Series: Legends of Time and Space (Dark City Games)

Name: Who, What, Where?
Description: This is a game for two teams. Each team takes turns to pick a who card and a what card and has two minutes to describe as many pairs as possible for their team mates to guess. Similar to charades but the player is allowed to talk, so long as they don't use any of the words on the cards. Examples of possible combinations are Hitler getting hit by bird poo and Sean Connery playing a didgeridoo.

Name: Goppa: The Game That Moves In Leaps & Bounds
Description:
A 2-player, 3-dimensional variation on Chinese Chess.  Players take turns making Chinese Chess style moves and leaps, but over a set of square grids that are staggered at different levels.  The board consists of 6 tiles, each having 16 spaces arranged in a 4x4 square.  The tiles are staggered in 3 different heights, and 3d moves are permitted between the tiles.  Players make extended Chinese checker jumps with their 16 marbles, trying to maneuver them in to opposing setup region.

---

From the Box (bad grammar authentically transcribed):
"If you enjoy the strategy of Chinese Checkers, the challenge of Backgammon you're sure to have a blast playing Goppa.

Object of the Game.  To be the first player to move all 16 of your marbles from your starting positions, across to the starting positions of your opponents marbles.

Helpful Hints.  There are 8 main strategic points on the game board.  These 8 points allow you to slow your opponent from making Goppa's (long jumps) from one side of the board all the way to the other side of the game board in one turn."

Name: Tri-Chinese Checkers
Description:
A 3-dimensional variant on Chinese Chess.  The board consists of 3 tiers.  All player pieces begin on the bottom tier, but the only way out is up to the middle tier.  The middle tier is an open grid, and connects to both the top and bottom tiers.  The top tier is a copy of the bottom tier, but reversed -- it contains the destinations that the players are racing to reach.  Each player tried to be the first one to get all 10 of his pieces from his starting zone on the bottom tier to his destination zone on the top tier, making standard Chinese chess moves and hops (but extended to 3d).

The game supports 2-4 players.

Name: Muumipeli
Description:
A children's roll and move game with memory game elements, based on the Moomin characters of Tove Jansson.

Moominpappa has lost his black top hats, and the players must help him to find them. The task is not easy, since the Moominhouse is suddenly full of black hats, not all of which belong to Moominpappa.

Players roll the dice to move their coloured, hat-shaped playing pieces on the track around the Moominhouse. When a player reaches a Moominpappa-circle she can take one of the hats from the Moominhouse and try it on her playing piece; if it fits, she can keep it (some of the hats are duds and will not fit on the playing pieces). Players can also steal hats from other players if they land in the same circle, and landing in the Hattifatteners-circle means that hats in the Moominhouse must be reshuffled.

The first player to reach Moominhouse with 2 or more hats is the winner.

Name: The Sun Board Game
Description:
"Play the game based on Britain's favourite newspaper."

This is a promo game for the UK tabloid, The Sun, and Virgin Mobile. Players are competing to edit the best version of the Sun, by first moving their journalist around the board to chase stories and then editing a version of the paper from the cards in their hands in a print run.

Stories fall in four categories (News, Sport, Features and Bizarre) and Editor's Choice (a kind of event/joker) and each edition must contain enough stories from each category. Categories are subdivided into sets of stories from the same news item. A few ads for Virgin Mobile are also included.

In the print runs, players place cards (stories) in front of them, one by one, and thus have a chance to select what stories they publish depending on their opponent's choices, and also affect the game with their Editor's Choices. Scoring is based on how many stories they have from the same set, if they have an exclusive of the news item, or if they were able to ruin another player's exclusive by also publishing a story from their set. The ads also score points. The player with the most points after the 4th print run wins.

Name: Euro-Tour
Description:
"MAN Super Truck: Mit dem Truck durch Europa - By truck through Europe"

This is a promo game for the German MAN truck company.

Players are truck drivers starting in Munich, Germany with the task to deliver cargo to five European cities. The five destinations are drawn randomly from the deck at the beginning of the game and kept secret; players can freely decide the order in which they visit their destinations and on the way, they may be helped or hindered by event cards. The first player to visit all five destinations and get back to Munich wins.

The game board is a map of Europe from the '80s and includes the national vehicle codes for the then existing European countries.

Name: Sulttaanin Jalokivet
Description:
Sultan's Gems

The players are adventurers looking for a hidden treasure in a non-specified Oriental land. The treasure is hidden in a cave, but first the players must visit three other way points (City, Oasis and Mountains). In the way points they can change their method of transport - by Foot (1 space at a time), by Camel (2 spaces) or Jeep (3 spaces). This is an important choice because on the way, they must pick up number cards from numbered spaces; entry to the cave requires a certain set of numbers, which may also change during the game. There are also event cards which may help or hinder the players.

Name: Tervapata
Description:
"An exciting game of chase"

This is a boardgame version of an old children's outdoor game. The game board is a circular track running around a boiling "pot of tar" (Tervapata). Each player has their own starting area with 4 playing pieces, which are moved by throwing 2 dice; players can choose whether to move two pieces, or to combine the results to move just one piece. Landing on an opponent's piece means that that piece immediately goes to the pot of tar, to be retrieved with a roll of 6 and then placed back to the owning player's starting area. This gives scope for some simple tactics: Should I try to concentrate on moving my own pieces as fast as possible, or to land on an opponent's pieces? And if so, whose?

The first player to get all 4 playing pieces to their goal area wins.

Paletti game no. 4047

Name: Play It Safe: The Farm Safety Challenge Game
Description:
This game is designed to help teachers and 4H group leaders teach kids about farm safety.  One person takes the role of game leader and runs the game without playing; everyone else splits into two, three or six teams.  Each team gets a farm animal paddle -- this paddle is passed from player to player within the team, and only the player holding the paddle at any given time may answer questions (though the whole team may influence those answers).

During play, teams take turns answering question cards in six categories: F.Y.I., In the Moos, You Herd It Here, Ouch, Seeing is Believing, and Heads Up.  Cards have a base point value of either 10 or 20 points, and all the 10-point cards are played before the 20-point cards.  All of the category cards feature a question about farm safety, and some also include bonus questions which can be answered for additional points if the first question is answered correctly.  Some cards require the players to look at large 11x14 photos showing farm activities and equipment.  Wild cards with general, non-farm-themed trivia may optionally be mixed in, and Daily Double cards may be added to force players to wager points on certain questions instead of using their face values.

The game leader decides the exact mix and number of cards, so the game can be weighted to favor particular topics and length of play can be shortened or lengthened as necessary.  Regardless of which cards are used during play, the game must be set up so that all teams get to answer the same number of questions, and the team with the most points at the end wins.

Name: Barbapapa: Ett kul förvandlings-spel
Description: The Barbapapa-family are on a picnic and they come across different places where Barbapapa and Barbamama needs to transform themselves so the children can pass. On the road they encounter a lot of garbage which they pick up. It is important to clean up and take care of nature. Everyone helps with the picking up but the one who has picked up the most and transformed it into flowers wins.

Name: Mythbusters DVD Game
Description:
Game contains gameboard, player tokens that are a washer, nut, wing nut, and bolt, and DVD.  DVD is used to show trivia and video clips to answer.

Video clips on DVD are from the Mythbusters TV series from the Discovery Channel.

Name: Raze the Castle!
Description:
Free print-and-play game about expanding your kingdom and protecting it from opponents' attackers and special invaders.

Each turn resolve events, pay upkeep, build structures and hire defenders. Play until one player's castle has been destroyed in combat, then largest and strongest kingdom wins.

Name: Sorry! Spider-Man 3
Description: This is a re-theme of the classic game, "Sorry!"  Based loosely on the movie, you can play as Spiderman, New Goblin, Sandman, or Venom.  The cards have been altered from the original game to give additional options, including many cards that will only help certain players (if those players happen to draw them).

Name: Paradox
Description:
A trivia game about quotes and clichés. The "board" is a 12 by 17 inch scroll.
Made in Winnipeg.

Name: Võidab see, kel on surres kõige rohkem asju
Description:
Another light game from Asko Künnap & Priit Isok. The title roughly translates as: "The winner is the one who has the most stuff when he/she dies." With a subtitle "Another absolutely useless item: a boardgame about owning!" In the game players madly run in a circle - like rats in a wheel - collecting useless luxurious items until the grim reaper stops the race.

At the beginning of the game each player has five items (cards). Items come in 6 colors with value from 1-5. A player's turn is a three-step affair:
1) Throw a die and move your pawn forward (clockwise in a circle). When you throw 1, the reaper also moves forward.
2) Do the action indicated by the space where your pawn landed. Most of the spaces are malls where you collect additional items but some spaces, like robber and recycling, take cards away. 
3) Gift an item to another player. You can gift only an item that matches the color of an item that an opponent already has and is of higher value.

The game ends when the reaper makes a full circle of eight steps. All players total the value of their cards and the player with the smallest total wins the game. That is, contrary to what the title claims, the winner is the player who has the least stuff in the end.

The emphasis of the game is obviously on fun. It is a family/party game which mocks the madness that takes hold of the “civilized” world just before any big gift-giving holiday. The items are titled such as "all types of USB cables" and "precious jewels for pets". The game was published just before Christmas and the board design closely resembles the logo of one of the leading chain of malls in Estonia. Unfortunately the game is available only in Estonian. Knowledge of the language is not essential but you will miss the fun titles of the cards.

Name: Action Vietnam
Description:
Published in Italy, this game comes in a large box measuring nearly 20 inches by 14 inches.  Rules printed in 11 languages including English.

A 2 player game that features miniatures trying to reach the far side of the game board and capturing predetermined spaces.  Somewhat abstract in application, this is a very low complexity game.

Vietnam theme is implied only by the incredibly cool game box.  Rules give no other indication that this is in any way a simulation of Vietnam warfare.

Name: Dan Russell's Hockey Trivia
Description: Compete against your friends answering the personal favorite hockey trivia questions of long time Vancouver sports radio talk show host Dan Russell.  The game focusses on questions about the Vancouver Canucks.

Name: Magnetic Baseball Travel Game
Description: Magnetic Baseball challenges two players to make the most runs in nine innings.  Flipping batter and pitcher cards instead of pitching and hitting a real ball, players employ the traditional rules of the all-American game.

Name: Family Night Frenzy
Description:
Family Night Frenzy is an Egyptian Ratscrew variant themed for an LDS audience.

From the publisher: Family Night Frenzy is a heart-pounding, card-slapping match and stack game for the whole family.

When the family gets together . . . things can get a little out of hand. And that’s the whole idea with Family Night Frenzy! It’s a free-for-all where everyone races to be the first to get rid of their cards by matching them and stacking them up. But you can’t stack until you’ve got a match, so keep drawing from the deck until you’ve got something to play. And don’t waste a second-this is quality time! Family Night Frenzy! A treat everyone will enjoy.

Make the treat, gather the kids, and let the frenzy begin!

Name: Time on Target: German Rare Vehicles
Description:
An Advanced Squad Leader System (ASL) compatible article published in Time On Target issue #3 - Focus on German rare vehicles.  Includes 64 full colour, die cut counters of rare vehicles, historical notes, vehicle notes to add to the ASL armoury, and 13 new scenarios to play these rare and not often seen vehicles.  Includes the 3 player DOGS OF WAR scenario.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader


Scenarios:

TOT 33: Another Tricky Day
TOT 34: Parry and Roposte
TOT 35: Death Knell at Kalach
TOT 36: Balkan Barbeque
TOT 37: Breaching Maloarkhangelsk
TOT 38: Bridge Busters
TOT 39: Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight
TOT 40: Ring of Fire
TOT 41: Tiger at the Gates
TOT 42: Thunderbolts
TOT 43: Jagdtiger, Jagtiger
TOT 44: A Dish Best Served Cold
TOT 45: The Dogs of War
TOT tC: Scorched Earth

Name: Deep Space DrillerAce
Description:
From the box:
Become a Deep Space DrillerAce. Oil and water are in short supply. The rulers of earth are becoming desperate. You and your opponent have been sent to the planet Arual where oil and water are abundant. Arual is inhabited by a superstitious race. The Arualians have agreed to allow you and your opponent to drill a maximum of 61 wells either for oil or water, but only at a strictly controlled rate. The Arualians are somewhat primitive and you have discovered that they revere a series of sacred symbols. When you place your Driller Domes in a pattern that resembles one of these symbols, the Arualians will allow you to drill wells at a faster rate. Your goal is to place more Driller Domes than your opponent and return home with the title of "Deep Space DrillerAce".

Deep Space DrillerAce is an abstract strategy game for 2 players. 
Players take turns placing glass Driller Domes on a hex board in an attempt to complete patterns that are shown on cards in their hand. When patterns are completed the player is allowed to immediately place more Driller Domes. The winner is the first player to place all 33 of his Driller Domes or the player with the most Domes on the board when it is completely filled.

The game comes with: 1 game board, 66 glass Driller Domes, 40 pattern cards and 1 rules sheet.

Name: Jesters
Description:
With so many games available that involve the leaders and royalty of medieval nations either battling each other or in competition with each other economically or socially, it is about time that a game came along that focuses on the real unsung heroes of those nations and kingdoms... the court jesters that entertained and provided much needed levity during those stressful times.

In Jesters, each player is an up-and-coming jester working on the medieval entertainment scene. To begin with, they are truly indie DIY performers and will be handling their own career and trying to book performances for themselves and win over fans.  As they progress, they may hook up with special persons like publicists and accountants and managers to be part of their entourage and help them achieve more success.  
        
There are several aspects of each jester's career which they will be working to advance over the five week Season of Mirth; Popularity, Wealth, Mojo, Reputation and Satisfaction. Jesters will also need to develop their material and save some of their best stuff for the big Woodshtick Festival at the end of the month, where all jesters are rated against each other and have the potential for a big payoff.

All of the wealth, fame and reputation in the world won't mean a thing if a jester can't get no satisfaction.  Jesters is ultimately won by the player who generates the most Satisfaction.  There are several ways to gain Satisfaction in the game; through great performances, through the support of people in your Entourage, and by having a lot of fans at the Festival.  Satisfaction Points can also be lost, through bad performances or other circumstances.

Jesters is played over five turns, each representing one week, with a final Festival performance at the end of the fifth week.  The game combines action drafting, hand management and area majority and plays in about 75-90 minutes.

Name: Pinky
Description:
I'll seek some clarification on this, but here is what I can glean at present:

Pinky is a large pink plastic pig that looks like a traditional piggy bank.  Set in Pinky's back is a slot which has a switch and a speaker, so that the game counts when players put in coins and occasionally "oinks".  It seems from the rules that players are putting coins in Pinky from a communal stock, but on a certain die-roll get to shake the pig to get coins back out; the coins that come out are a player's score pile for the end of the game.

Name: Time Machine
Description:
A Time Machine has been set in motion before it was sufficiently tested... Its team of developers may end up being stuck in an endless loop cycle between the time it was first activated (4 minutes ago), the time it was first launched (now) and the time it can be relaunched (4 minutes into the future).

Time and player movement is kept track of on a board depicting one minute intervals between the first activation and the second launch. Gameplay involves players drawing and placing numbered/colored hexes. At the beginning of the game, before the first time machine launch, a line of hexes is laid out to create the sequence of events that led to the time machine being built. Then, after the first launch, each turn uses a new hex sequence where players try to recreate the sequence of events that created the first launch while also "fixing" it just enough to make it work correctly and hopefully break them all out of the loop. One aspect of the gameplay uses actual one minute time measures as part of the process.

Adding to the challenge, each time a player goes back in time, there is another one of them added to the game (depicting someone from the present traveling back in time and encountering themselves in the past). A light/dark color scheme is used to distinguish the present/past player tokens (dark blue/light blue, dark green/light green, etc.).  Each new version of a player adds abilities and also causes potential problems, and there is a limit to the number of multiples a single player can have before the time line is destroyed beyond repair.

Play is cooperative, with a special commendation for the team member(s) who had the biggest part in fixing the machine. A game may also include a saboteur who is trying to subtly destroy the machine and prevent any progress in the field of time travel.

Name: Mountebanks
Description:
Each player is a particularly slimy snake oil salesman, traveling between different regions, trying to sell their elixirs to eager balding or ailing customers.

Each area has a different population and gullibility rating, so the potential for success and for higher sales will differ from region to region. Only one player can perform a sales demonstration in a particular area at a given time, though, so before each turn, there is a simultaneous action selection for where each player goes and what they intend to do. If more than one player chooses the same area, then neither of them can demonstrate there, or they may choose to resolve who will get to demonstrate there. A player's success will depend on their ability to sell, the effectiveness and pizzazz of their pitch, and the saleability of their product. Players bid from among different available elixirs and can choose to spend time rehearsing their pitches or watching other players demonstrate in order to improve their ability to sell.

Once a player has successfully demonstrated in an area, there will then be a limited number of turns before that area will become dangerous for other salesmen... The people of that region will soon realize that the last product they bought was bogus and they will be more skeptical of new salesmen coming to town. Later in the game, salesmen may have no choice but to try to sell to places that are already very skeptical or even downright hostile towards them, and will have to use special abilities gained throughout the game (including disguises, new pitches, flashier gimmicks, etc.) in order to succeed.

Particularly bitter areas will send out police or mobs after the shysters, and so players must be careful to avoid being jailed or injured, which will set back their efforts. Players may also work together at times in order to protect or vouch for each other, but of course, alliances made among scoundrels aren't likely to last...

After a certain number of regions in the area have become hostile, all players must make it to a train station within another turn in order to escape.  The player who escapes with the most money is the winner.

Name: Scramble!
Description:
This is basically a two-player version of the 1970's game Perfection, in which you have a set of plastic shapes that fit into holes on the board.  The board is pushed down into a spring-loaded box with a timer.  When you fit all your shapes into the right holes, you turn off the timer.  If you don't turn it off in time, it pops and sends all your pieces flying.

Scramble! is exactly like that except each player has his own set of pieces, and you play on opposite sides of the game unit.  There are 18 pieces for each player.  The game also includes a "junior version", which amounts to a piece of cardboard that covers up six of the holes.

Name: Princess Wishes Card Game
Description:
Players compete to collect the most cards by recalling through memory the sequence of cards put into play.

The game is based on the Disney Princess license.

Name: Yacht Race
Description:
Typical Edwardian children's race style board game based on yachting. Each player throws a six-sided dice and moves their counter (yacht) as many divisions as indicated on the dice. Penalties and privileges are paid on specific divisions that help and hinder the player getting to the finish line.
The first player to cross the finish line wins the game.

Name: Chung Kuo Chung Tzu (Chinese Gentleman)
Description:
The game box includes four sets of colored wooden blocks used to complete & build a Chinese gentleman (head, arms, legs, torso, feet & coolie style hat), a removable bulls-eye target tray for throwing the six supplied colored beans (dice) into, and a small rules leaflet. 
Players take turns using the supplied dice box, to throw six uniquely colored beans that match the colored blocks used to build the figure, into the tray in order to try and place a specific color nearest the center of the tray (a bulls-eye style display facilitates this). The color throw nearest the center must match up to a part of the Chinese gentleman to be built. Builds must be in order: feet, legs, torso, arms, head and finally hat.
The first player to complete his/her 'Chinese Gentleman' wins the game.

Name: Pot-Luc
Description:
The game box contains a play mat/poster and a set of three six sided dice engraved with letters instead of numbers (except for one that also contains numbers and one other with a blank side). Any number of players may play. 
The play mat is Irish themed and bears no other impact on the game apart from providing an area where betting chips may be placed.
A banker is elected by throwing the only lettered dice that also contains a number, the highest number gets the bank first. Players place chips (bets) on any combination of the ten spaces provided on the play mat as a first action. Next, the three dice are thrown and the result matched up with three lettered word combinations indicated on the ten spaces of the board. Players with chips placed in the same named board space as the word rolled, receive between two & seven times the amount bet depending on the number rolled on one of the dice combinations. The banker collects all loosing chips and also if a word is rolled that has not been bet upon by any player. The banker looses the bank when one of the dice turns up blank and a new banker is selected amongst the other players as indicated above.
